NEW YORK.
FRIDAY, NOVEMBER 11, 1887.

RAILWAY MATTERS.

Canadians are not so bad in this country as they seem to be on the other side of the ocean. The unemployed in London are showing their strength by the fact that they ask for work to be given them, and no doubt many of them are anxious for something to do, but it always happens in cases of this kind that the employed class are too weak to turn out and take part in labor demonstrations and help to swell the crowd. A compact population in Britain usually finds relief by the strong current flowing into the country. Our unemployed always get their share. At present Canada is not in want of additional immigrants of that class, the labor market being amply supplied. It is long overdue for those setting in and little thought made for those who are already out of employment, the outlook for outside labor as far as Canada is concerned is very bright. Sympathy for even an old of employ- ment is well enough in its place, but the men themselves would much rather have employment than sympathy.

It has been apparent all along notwithstanding what is being said by commercial unionists, that the fishery commission will deal only with fishermen, leaving the question of wages, hours, and conditions to be settled by the employers. It is not at all likely that our neighbors will accept any settlement that will enable them to pay less cash for the fish they purchase from us. When the Halifax award was made, giving Canada five and a half millions of dollars for twelve years' use of the fisheries, the United States took all the fish they could get, doing a great deal of grumbling, and ever since that time our Yankee cousins have protested that they were swindled in the transaction, but they will take good care that the coming Canadian award gets the start of them again. There is plenty of fish in the sea for everybody who desires to catch them, and what is very likely to be the outcome of the whole affair is that the fishermen in an agreement that American fishermen shall be permitted to fish within the Canadian three mile limit on condition that Canadian fish shall be admitted free to the United States. This is something very much less than the unrestricted reciprocity of which we hear so much. It will be unrestricted reciprocity, indeed, but only in fish. Our neighbors have every reason to use the Canadian fisheries, and, though Canada does not like manufacturing but business, and the like common sense will impel the people of the Saskatchewan to seek the shortest route to their final market. Another thing is that the opening of the new railway promises that hard arsion. If free railway communication with the United States is to be opened up, there is no good reason why the people of the north to south Winnipeg for eastward trade should not be able to do so. The people of Ontario may aspire to be the distributing point, with a line leading direct to Western Manitoba at Brad- ford. If railway competition is to be had at all, it will be a competition for Manitobans, not a scheme of putting money into the pockets of Win- nipeg. If new railways are to be built, Western Manitoba should not consider the possibility of securing to produce all the way to Brad- ford. Short routes must be built in the interests of the farmers. Winnipeg is not the whole of Mani- toba. Still less is it the whole of the North-west.

FREE PRESS, WINNIPEG, MAN.
The Northwest Council

Thursday, Oct. 20

Ordinance respecting bulls given its second reading.

Moved by Mr. Carlyle, seconded by Mr. Turrit—That the Dominion Government be requested to send people of the North West to the forthcoming session of members of the North West Legislative Assembly. This motion may be an occasion of granting either a license or a special prohibition system in the North West, and the question may be raised regarding liquor question he introduced by the Dominion Government upon the result of such legislation.

Mr. Turrit introduced a bill repealing Agricultural Societies, which was read a second time.

Council went into Committee of Whole on bill for the repeal of certain clauses of the Agricultural Societies Act. An interesting discussion took place on clause 2. Messrs. Sewell, Wilson, and Hamilton claimed that the act was intended to prevent the formation of new societies unless they wished, and Messrs. Crawford, Ross, Turrit, and Sinclair contended that the act was only intended to prevent the formation of new societies unless they wished.

Bill regarding certain clauses of Compulsory Ordinance was given its second and third readings and ordered printed.

Friday, Oct. 21

All the members present at day's close except Judge Richard and Messrs. Macarthur, Wilson, and Sewell.

Mr. Carlyle presented a petition from the farmers of the district, praying that an ordinance be passed to reduce the rate of tax on non-residents who did not reside within the district.

It was finally decided to refer the bill back to the special committee, for a second consideration.

Bill establishing Provincial Police was given its second and third readings and ordered printed.

DIRECTORY

At the request of a number of influential citizens, I have the honor to inform you that the following directory is now completed:

It will embrace, besides the usual matter comprising the names and addresses of the firms and persons of the various towns and villages of the district, and giving a brief report for the same, the following additional matters:

A list of prominent citizens of Prince Albert and vicinity, and a list of prominent citizens residing outside the district, giving their place of residence and occupation.

No pains will be spared to make it complete and useful to the citizens and businessmen men and others.

A list of prominent citizens residing at the various points in the district, with the subdivision to which each subdivision will be assigned in the directory.

Orders for copies of Directory may be directed to J. D. Maveety, Publisher, or any prominent citizen residing in the district.

In order that the above enter-

ments shall be made at once, immediately, the publishers respectfully request that they be sent in promptly by the subscribers, and as promptly as possible by the subscribers, and as promptly as possible by the publishers.

H. E. HILL
Prince Albert, Sask.

All present subscribers will be credited for the amount paid up to the date now. New Subscribers will be charged Twenty-five cents for the first half-year's subscription. "Coming from the East," No. 27 inclusive, will be sent to subscribers placing the First-Class postage in advance on the address label, or by mailing the liberal offer now made. It is the intention of the publishers to make the contents of the Journal published by the Canadian North Western Farmers' Association, as nearly as possible, and as promptly as possible, in accordance with the liberal offer now made, and the latest and best information advantageously published.

NORTH-WEST FARMER,

Winnipeg, Man.
TOWN COUNCIL.

The regular monthly meeting of the Town Council was held on Monday evening last.

Council Stewart, Bain and Agnew were the only members present at the meeting.

Council Stewart was appointed chairman, and the minutes of last meeting were read and adopted.

CONSIDERATION.

A communication was received from the secretary of School District No. 3, requesting payment of balance due said district.

Also came from Mr. Charles Woodman, tendering his resignation as postmaster.

APPLICATIONS.

Applications for city licenses were received from James Taylor, J.M. Campbell, Mr. McKeever, and from P. Campbell for license for restaurant.

COMMITTEE.

Council Stewart introduced a by-law to close road on river lot 72 and continue Saskatchewan avenue through said property.

REPORTS.

The treasurer and license inspector each presented their report for month of October.

WORKS AND HEALTH.

Council Bain, chairman of Works and Health Committee, reported that there had been little work done, but that the large hoppers had been repaired. In conclusion, he stated that D. Wilson be paid $250 on account of his contract, as recommended by the engineer. Adopted.

FINANCE AND ASSESSMENT.

Council Stewart, chairman of the Finance and Assessment Committee, recommended payment of the following accounts:

McKee & Macdonald, $40; J. Nelson, $10; McBeath, $8; Wm. Tait, $40; Waller & Baker, $8; T. J. Agnew, $8; C. Byers, $23. Adopted.

RESIGNATION.

Council Agnew informed if the cases appealed to the Court of Revision had been decided yet.

The by-law introduced by Council Stewart was read first, second and third time, and passed. Ordered to be signed, sealed and returned.

RESIGNATION.

The resignation of Mr. C. Woodman as postmaster for the east end was accepted.

The Council then adjourned, to meet on Monday, 21st inst., at the usual hour.

SCHOOL BOARD.

The first meeting of the Board of Trustees elected Mr. Bain chairman in the absence of Mr. McBeath.

Present—Messrs. Bettis, Davis and Campbell.

On motion of Messrs. Campbell and Davis, Mr. Bettis was appointed chairman.

Moved by Mr. Davis, seconded by Mr. Campbell, that Mr. Scott be secretary at a salary of $25. Carried.

Moved by Mr. Davis, seconded by Mr. Bettis, that Mr. Scott be treasurer, at a salary of $5. Carried.

Moved by Mr. Davis, seconded by Mr. Campbell, that a list of duties be printed for priests at the end of the present term, the same to be given for at least two terms. Carried.

The Secretary was instructed to ask the Town Council for balance of money due the teacher, and also to advertise for a teacher for the junior classes, at a salary of $300.

The Board then adjourned.

On Wednesday evening last, at St. Paul's Church, Lindsay, an amusingly formal ceremony took place. The two daughters of Mr. Foulds—Flora and Sarah—were united in the happy bonds of wedlock. The ceremony took place in the South Branch, and the latter to Mr. S. Lewis. Mr. Brown and his bride were similarly joined, the ceremony being performed by Rev. Mr. McPhail, minister of the bride, and Mr. Leask and his wife by Rev. Mr. McLaughlin and Miss Anna Adams. The marriage was performed by the Rev. Canon Firth. Quite a number of our citizens were present, and the occasion was marked by the most charming and beautiful. We extend our best wishes to Mr. and Mrs. Brown and Mr. and Mrs. Lewis, and trust this is only a foretelling of the future of our country's young grooms.
